title: Top-K Tracker (Hard Version)
statementHtml:
This is an interactive problem.

This is the hard version of the problem. The only difference is that n≤890n≤890 in this version. You can make hacks only if all versions of the problem are solved.

There is a hidden permutation pp, which is a permutation of {1,2,…,n}{1,2,…,n}. Let posiposi denote the position of the value ii in pp, i.e., pospi=ipospi=i.

To find this permutation, you can ask four types of queries:

Let cici be the usage count of queries of type ii (1≤i≤4)(1≤i≤4). Your query count must satisfy the following constraints:
inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤401≤t≤40). The description of the test cases follows.

Interaction

The first line of each test case contains one integer nn (2≤n≤8902≤n≤890). At this moment, the permutation pp is chosen. The interactor in this task is not adaptive. In other words, the permutation pp is fixed in every test case and does not change during the interaction.

To ask a query of type 11, you need to print the line of the following form (without quotes):

  • "1 m i1 i2 … im1 m i1 i2 … im" (1≤m≤n1≤m≤n, i1,i2,…,imi1,i2,…,im must be distinct)

After that, you receive k=min(60,m)k=min(60,m) integer(s) — the top kk largest number(s) in [pi1,pi2,…,pim][pi1,pi2,…,pim] in increasing order.

To ask a query of type 22, you need to print the line of the following form (without quotes):

  • "2 m i1 i2 … im2 m i1 i2 … im" (1≤m≤n1≤m≤n, i1,i2,…,imi1,i2,…,im must be distinct)

After that, you receive k=min(60,m)k=min(60,m) integer(s) — the top kk largest number(s) in [posi1,posi2,…,posim][posi1,posi2,…,posim] in increasing order.

To ask a query of type 33, you need to print the line of the following form (without quotes):

  • "3 m i1 i2 … im3 m i1 i2 … im" (1≤m≤n1≤m≤n, i1,i2,…,imi1,i2,…,im must be distinct)

After that, you receive k=min(300,m)k=min(300,m) integer(s) — the top kk largest number(s) in [pi1,pi2,…,pim][pi1,pi2,…,pim] in increasing order.

To ask a query of type 44, you need to print the line of the following form (without quotes):

  • "4 m i1 i2 … im4 m i1 i2 … im" (1≤m≤n1≤m≤n, i1,i2,…,imi1,i2,…,im must be distinct)

After that, you receive k=min(300,m)k=min(300,m) integer(s) — the top kk largest number(s) in [posi1,posi2,…,posim][posi1,posi2,…,posim] in increasing order.

Next, if your program has found the permutation pp, print the line of the following form (without quotes):

  • "! p1 p2 … pn! p1 p2 … pn"

Note that this line is not considered a query and is not taken into account when counting the number of queries asked.

After this, proceed to the next test case.

After printing a query or the answer for a test case, do not forget to output the end of the line and flush the output. Otherwise, you will get the verdict Idleness Limit Exceeded. To do this, use:

  • fflush(stdout) or cout.flush() in C++;
  • System.out.flush() in Java;
  • flush(output) in Pascal;
  • stdout.flush() in Python;
  • see the documentation for other languages.

Hacks

To hack, follow the test format below.

The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤401≤t≤40). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains one integer nn (2≤n≤8902≤n≤890).

The second line of each test case contains nn integers p1,p2,…,pnp1,p2,…,pn, which is a permutation of {1,2,…,n}{1,2,…,n}.
noteHtml:
In the first test case, the hidden permutation is p=[3,1,2]p=[3,1,2]. Thus, pos=[2,3,1]pos=[2,3,1].

For the query "3 2 3 1", the jury returns 22 and 33 because 22 and 33 are the top kk largest number(s) in [p3,p1][p3,p1], where k=min(300,m)=min(300,2)=2k=min(300,m)=min(300,2)=2.

For the query "2 1 2", the jury returns 33 because 33 is the top kk largest number in [pos2][pos2], where k=min(60,m)=min(60,1)=1k=min(60,m)=min(60,1)=1.

Note that the example is only for understanding the statement and does not guarantee finding the unique permutation pp.
